title: Bovichtidae
text:
Bovichtidae, the temperate icefishes or thornfishes, is a <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> of marine <a href="ray-finned%20fish">ray-finned fish</a>es, classified in the suborder <a href="Notothenioidei">Notothenioidei</a> of the <a href="Order%20%28biology%29">order</a> <a href="Perciformes">Perciformes</a>. They are native to coastal waters off <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>.
Systematics.
Bovichtidae was first formally described as a family in 1861 by the American <a href="ichthyologist">ichthyologist</a> <a href="Theodore%20Nicholas%20Gill">Theodore Nicholas Gill</a>. The family name was spelled Bovichthyidae in the 4th edition of J. S. Nelson's "<a href="Fishes%20of%20the%20World">Fishes of the World</a>" but has been reverted to Bovichtidae in the 5th edition. Phylogenetic analysis of morphological characters has revealed that the family Bovichtidae may not be a monophyletic group. Bovichtidae is one of two families of the suborder <a href="Notothenioidei">Notothenioidei</a> with a primarily non-Antarctic distribution, the other being <a href="Pseudaphritis%20urvillii">Pseudaphritidae</a>. The name of the family is taken from its <a href="type%20genus">type genus</a>, "Bovichtus" which is derived from bovus meaning “bull” and "ichthys" which means fish, based on the local name for "Bovichtus" species in <a href="Valparaiso">Valparaiso</a>, Chile, "torrito", the “little bull”.
The Bovichtidae is the <a href="Sister%20taxa">sister</a> family to the Pseudaphritidae which in turn is sister to the <a href="Eleginopidae">Eleginopidae</a> and these are all sister to the rest of the families in the Notothenoidei which have been placed in the suggested <a href="Superfamily%20%28biology%29">superfamily</a> <a href="Cryonotothenioidea">Cryonotothenioidea</a>. The Bovichtidae are regarded as the most <a href="Basal%20%28phylogenetics%29">basal</a> family in the suborder.
Genera.
Currently, three genera are included in this family, with the <a href="catadromous">catadromous</a> genus "<a href="Pseudaphritis">Pseudaphritis</a>" now being placed in its own family, Pseudaphritidae.
Characteristics.
Bovichtidae icefishes are characterised by a protrusible a not very elongated or pronounced snout. The gill membranes not connected to the <a href="Glossary%20of%20ichthyology">isthmus</a> and they project quite far forward. There is a single <a href="lateral%20line">lateral line</a>. They have a long, compressed body with two dorsal fins, the front dorsal fin being spiny. There are no spines in the anal fin. There is a spine on the operculum which may be weak and flattened or robust, long and pointed. There is a single nostril on the snout. There are small conical teeth on the jaws, <a href="vomer">vomer</a> and <a href="Palatine%20bone">palatine</a>. There is no <a href="swim%20bladder">swim bladder</a>.
Distribution and habitat.
Bovichtidae species are found in the southern hemisphere where they occur in marine waters off southern South America, southern Australia and New Zealand.
